summary: The End of time
title: The End of time
body:
Putting aside all of my feelings towards this two-parter which are sour for obvious reasons. 

I believe that The End of time part 2 is one of the best episodes of doctor who simply based on the performances of David Tennant and Bernard Cribbins. The two of them together made quite possibly the best duo I’ve ever seen and Tennants emotional and compelling ‘monologue’ at the end just after the time lords have been defeated really captures the pain that The Doctor feels.

Just decided to share that with you. Have a good day

reblog.comment:

blog.name: incorrectnewwho
blog.title: Incorrect Doctor Who
blog.description:
Could have been said in another time, or another universe...
~Wibbly-wobbly, timey-wimey~

summary: 10: Things could be worse, you know. Martha: How? 10: How what? Martha: How could they be worse? 10: They couldn’t. I lied.
body:
10: Things could be worse, you know.

Martha: How?

10: How what?

Martha: How could they be worse?

10: They couldn’t. I lied.

tags: thank heavens DT and Phil agree that the Doctor wasn't actually drunk
that he was just playing drunk to confuse the clockwork men
it does bother me a bit that Moffat wrote the Doctor as actually drunk
I'm fully on the fake-drunk side
and bless poor DT - who is allergic to horses
I agree with Phil - the stuff they put him through
summary:
Behind the Scenes of the The Girl in the Fireplace (Part 7) 

  

Excerpt from the DVD Commentary with David Tennant, Phil...
caption:
Behind the Scenes of the The Girl in the Fireplace (Part 7)

Excerpt from the DVD Commentary with David Tennant, Phil Collinson (Producer) and Sophia Myles (Madame de Pompadour)

[ concerning the clock on the spinning fireplace ]
David Tennant: It is worth charting, if you’re as pedantic as I am, the clocks - when they’re broken and when they’re not, and when they spin ‘round.
Phil Collinson: Yes.  Did we ever get it wrong?
DT: I remember having long discussions with it, the assumption being that on Reinette’s side it would get fixed, but on the side that span out it would remain broken so that when you span back it would be broken on that side but then fixed again on the other side until is span back…   It’s the sort of thing that interests me on a long shooting day
PC: [laughs]  As if you haven’t got enough to do
——–
[ talking about the Doctor being intoxicated (or not) ]
DT: Lots of debates on this scene as to how drunk one can… whether he is being drunk or just exuberant or…
PC: Yes.  What do you think?
DT: Well, ultimately it’s all a ruse, isn’t it?  So I thought play it to the hilt, really, because in a few seconds we’ll see that it’s all just to get through the defenses of the clockwork men, but I know that we did have a bit of a debate as to whether the Doctor could be seen as intoxicated, didn’t we?
PC: Yes, we did.  I think ultimately you’re right.  It’s a ruse to get though the defenses of the clockwork men
DT: Yeah
PC: …and actually it’s terribly funny
DT: I think Steven Moffat wrote it drunk, certainly. It was in the stage directions, wasn’t it?
PC: Yeah.  He’d had a few banana daiquiris.
DT: Yeah [ all laugh ]
——–
[ talking about actually David riding the horse and the horse not being allowed in the ballroom ]
PC:  You did have to learn to jump on the horse, didn’t you?
DT:  Oh yeah
PC: You properly went to a paddock with a green screen and jumped.  Dear goodness - the stuff we’ve put you through…
DT: [ laughs ]


Other parts of this photoset:  [ one ] [ two ] [ three ] [ four ] [ five ] [ six ]
Other behind-the-scenes photosets are available here
